issue.title: Add M1 benchmarking code
issue.body:
This adds M1 benchmarking code based on based on https://gist.github.com/dougallj/5bafb113492047c865c0c8cfbc930155. 

@potsrevennil @hanno-becker, please test this on your M1 devices. Can you also each run it maybe 3 times and post the results here , so we can make sure we are getting stable results? 

Currently this requires to be run as the `root` user, so I added a flag `--run-as-root` to the benchmarking script, but this may require the user to enter a password. If anyone knows a way to use performance counters on Apple Silicon without using `sudo`, please do let me know. 

I'd like to point out that this code has caused me significant pain. 
The original code contains two calls to `configure_rdtsc()` right after each other. I thought this must be a mistake and naively removed one of the calls. This resulted in the code working fine on a M1 MacMini, but reporting wrong numbers (like 0/1/2/3/4 cycles rather than serveral 10ks) on mulitple different MacBooks we have tried.
After some trial-and-error, we found out that the calls within  `configure_rdtsc()` seem to be in the wrong order resulting in some of them being ineffective on the first invocation (on some devices). 
This is fixed by reordering
`kpc_set_config`, `kpc_force_all_ctrs_set`, `kpc_set_counting`, `kpc_set_thread_counting`
to 
`kpc_force_all_ctrs_set`, `kpc_set_counting`, `kpc_set_thread_counting`, `kpc_set_config`.
Thanks @hanno-becker for helping me with that!

Then it should work with a single call to `configure_rdtsc`.

comment.body: Thanks for the review @hanno-becker. I implemented all your suggestions.

issue.title: Add M1 benchmarking code
issue.body:
This adds M1 benchmarking code based on based on https://gist.github.com/dougallj/5bafb113492047c865c0c8cfbc930155. 

@potsrevennil @hanno-becker, please test this on your M1 devices. Can you also each run it maybe 3 times and post the results here , so we can make sure we are getting stable results? 

Currently this requires to be run as the `root` user, so I added a flag `--run-as-root` to the benchmarking script, but this may require the user to enter a password. If anyone knows a way to use performance counters on Apple Silicon without using `sudo`, please do let me know. 

I'd like to point out that this code has caused me significant pain. 
The original code contains two calls to `configure_rdtsc()` right after each other. I thought this must be a mistake and naively removed one of the calls. This resulted in the code working fine on a M1 MacMini, but reporting wrong numbers (like 0/1/2/3/4 cycles rather than serveral 10ks) on mulitple different MacBooks we have tried.
After some trial-and-error, we found out that the calls within  `configure_rdtsc()` seem to be in the wrong order resulting in some of them being ineffective on the first invocation (on some devices). 
This is fixed by reordering

to

Thanks @hanno-becker for helping me with that!

Then it should work with a single call to `configure_rdtsc`.

comment.body:
I added a flag for setting the taskpolicy. 
This allows to run on the E-cores (Icestorm) explicitly: 
```
$ tests bench -c M1 --run-as-root --mac-taskpolicy background
INFO  > benchmark
INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber512 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM512
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=101065
encaps cycles=132484
decaps cycles=168400
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  1632
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  800
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 768

INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber768 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM768
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=174056
encaps cycles=216116
decaps cycles=262737
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  2400
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  1184
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 1088

INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber1024 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM1024
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=279481
encaps cycles=327385
decaps cycles=385768
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  3168
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  1568
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 1568
```

Internally this runs: 
```
taskpolicy -c background sudo ./test/bin/bench_kyberXXX
```

There seems to be no way to force it to the P-cores (Firestorm), see https://eclecticlight.co/2022/01/24/how-you-cant-promote-threads-on-an-m1/. 
But it seems that our code ends up on the P-cores all the time if we do not set any `taskpolicy`: 
```
$ tests bench -c M1 --run-as-root                            
INFO  > benchmark
INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber512 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM512
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=60602
encaps cycles=75159
decaps cycles=93534
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  1632
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  800
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 768

INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber768 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM768
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=102951
encaps cycles=122882
decaps cycles=146227
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  2400
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  1184
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 1088

INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber1024 CYCLES=M1
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM1024
INFO  > 
keypair cycles=160584
encaps cycles=183860
decaps cycles=214008
CRYPTO_SECRETKEYBYTES:  3168
CRYPTO_PUBLICKEYBYTES:  1568
CRYPTO_CIPHERTEXTBYTES: 1568
```

issue.title: Add M1 benchmarking code

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

issue.body:
This adds M1 benchmarking code based on based on https://gist.github.com/dougallj/5bafb113492047c865c0c8cfbc930155. 

~@potsrevennil @hanno-becker, please test this on your M1 devices. Can you also each run it maybe 3 times and post the results here , so we can make sure we are getting stable results?~ 
Results seem stable accross 4 different M1 devices (MacMini and various MacBook). 

To run on the P-cores (Firestorm), run 
```
tests bench -c M1 --run-as-root   
```

To run on the E-cores (Icestorm), run 
```
tests bench -c M1 --run-as-root --mac-taskpolicy background
```

Internally this runs:
```
taskpolicy -c background sudo ./test/bin/bench_kyberXXX
```

Currently this requires to be run as the `root` user, so I added a flag `--run-as-root` to the benchmarking script, but this may require the user to enter a password. If anyone knows a way to use performance counters on Apple Silicon without using `sudo`, please do let me know. 

I'd like to point out that this code has caused me significant pain. 
The original code contains two calls to `configure_rdtsc()` right after each other. I thought this must be a mistake and naively removed one of the calls. This resulted in the code working fine on a M1 MacMini, but reporting wrong numbers (like 0/1/2/3/4 cycles rather than serveral 10ks) on mulitple different MacBooks we have tried.
After some trial-and-error, we found out that the calls within  `configure_rdtsc()` seem to be in the wrong order resulting in some of them being ineffective on the first invocation (on some devices). 
This is fixed by reordering
`kpc_set_config`, `kpc_force_all_ctrs_set`, `kpc_set_counting`, `kpc_set_thread_counting`
to 
`kpc_force_all_ctrs_set`, `kpc_set_counting`, `kpc_set_thread_counting`, `kpc_set_config`.
Thanks @hanno-becker for helping me with that!

Then it should work with a single call to `configure_rdtsc`.

issue.title: static link glibc into nix gcc for aarch64 and x86_64 linux
issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In the `nix` shell, we specify that `gcc` is downloaded from arm gnu official website for `x86_64` linux, and use the nixpkgs `gcc` for `aarch64` linux. 

However glibc only comes as a dynamic library in both cases, making compiling with `-static` result in error: 
```
ld: cannot find -lc: No such file or directory
```

Now I added glibc static library as a dependency, and configured it into one of the gcc default search path. Additional context, some package manager like `pacman` in `archlinux` packed the gcc with glibc, so that compilation with `-static` works automatically in this case.

@hanno-becker @mkannwischer Please have a look and see if the static compilation works, and the original usage won't break. The static compilation can be tested such as:
```
CFLAGS="-mcpu=cortex-a55 -march=armv8.2-a -static" make bench CYCLES=PERF
```

I've also cleanup the nix file a bit, hope that it can be more readable and easier to maintain.
<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body:
It's likely worth to mention that static compilation is a prerequisite for benchmarking on some platforms. 
For example, Cortex-A55 (A78/X1) is a Snapdragon 888 which is running Android. Running statically linked binaries is easy, but currently we don't have a way to run dynamically linked binaries there. 
Hence, this problem came up and turned out much more annoying than we anticipated it to be.

issue.title: static link glibc into nix gcc for aarch64 and x86_64 linux
issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In the `nix` shell, we specify that `gcc` is downloaded from arm gnu official website for `x86_64` linux, and use the nixpkgs `gcc` for `aarch64` linux. 

However glibc only comes as a dynamic library in both cases, making compiling with `-static` result in error: 
```
ld: cannot find -lc: No such file or directory
```

Now I added glibc static library as a dependency, and configured it into one of the gcc default search path. Additional context, some package manager like `pacman` in `archlinux` packed the gcc with glibc, so that compilation with `-static` works automatically in this case.

@hanno-becker @mkannwischer Please have a look and see if the static compilation works, and the original usage won't break. The static compilation can be tested such as:
```
CFLAGS="-mcpu=cortex-a55 -march=armv8.2-a -static" make bench CYCLES=PERF
```

I've also cleanup the nix file a bit, hope that it can be more readable and easier to maintain.
<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body: @mkannwischer Thanks for the additional information!

issue.title: static link glibc into nix gcc for aarch64 and x86_64 linux
issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
In the `nix` shell, we specify that `gcc` is downloaded from arm gnu official website for `x86_64` linux, and use the nixpkgs `gcc` for `aarch64` linux. 

However glibc only comes as a dynamic library in both cases, making compiling with `-static` result in error: 
```
ld: cannot find -lc: No such file or directory
```

Now I added glibc static library as a dependency, and configured it into one of the gcc default search path. Additional context, some package manager like `pacman` in `archlinux` packed the gcc with glibc, so that compilation with `-static` works automatically in this case.

@hanno-becker @mkannwischer Please have a look and see if the static compilation works, and the original usage won't break. The static compilation can be tested such as:
```
CFLAGS="-mcpu=cortex-a55 -march=armv8.2-a -static" make bench CYCLES=PERF # aarch64
CFLAGS="-mcpu=cortex-a55 -march=armv8.2-a -static" CROSS_PREFIX=aarch64-none-linux-gnu- make bench CYCLES=PERF # x86_64
```

I've also cleanup the nix file a bit, hope that it can be more readable and easier to maintain.
<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body:
I tested this PR on my RPi4 (AArch64) and my x86 machine. 
On x86 I hadd to add `CROSS_PREFIX=aarch64-linux-gnu-`, but then it works fine. 
The resulting benchmarking binaries work fine on the A55. 

I also checked that this does not break the native and qemu tests.

issue.title: Test Mac benchmarks in CI

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

comment.body:
It's not looking like we can perform Mac benchmarks on the standard github runners: 
https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/actions/runs/9708795475/job/26796245343?pr=83
```
 tests bench -c M1 --run-as-root -v
  shell: /nix/var/nix/profiles/default/bin/nix develop .#ci -c bash -e {0}
  env:
    DETERMINATE_NIX_KVM: 0
    MAGIC_NIX_CACHE_DAEMONDIR: /Users/runner/work/_temp/magic-nix-cache-05540193-7c2f-4fe8-aefc-8b29c1fa6d4b
INFO  > benchmark
DEBUG > Running test/bin/bench_kyber512 natively
INFO  > make test/bin/bench_kyber512 CYCLES=M1
  GEN     test/obj/.config.mk
  CC      test/bin/bench_kyber512
gcc  -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Werror -Wmissing-prototypes -Wredundant-decls -Wshadow -Wpointer-arith -Wno-unknown-pragmas -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -pedantic -I mlkem -I fips202  -DM1_CYCLES -I randombytes -DKYBER_K=2 mlkem/kem.c mlkem/indcpa.c mlkem/polyvec.c mlkem/poly.c mlkem/ntt.c mlkem/cbd.c mlkem/reduce.c mlkem/verify.c fips202/keccakf1600.c fips202/fips202.c mlkem/symmetric-shake.c randombytes/randombytes.c test/hal.c test/bench_kyber.c -o test/bin/bench_kyber512
INFO  > Running benchmarks as root -- you may need to enter your root password.
INFO  > MLKEM512
INFO  > 
kpc_force_all_ctrs_set failed
kpc_get_thread_counters failed
kpc_get_thread_counters failed
kpc_get_thread_counters failed
kpc_get_thread_counters failed
kpc_get_thread_counters failed
...
```
Seems these runners don't have access to the performance counters. 
Not entirely surprising, but I thought I give it a try.

issue.title: Add benchmarking code
issue.body:
I'd like to have benchmarking code here for at least the following 3 cases
- `PMU` cycles for platforms 
- `PERF` performance for systems where access to the `PMU` cycles counters is not possible, but perf is compiled into the Kernel.
-  `APPLE`  for Apple Mx cores based on https://gist.github.com/dougallj/5bafb113492047c865c0c8cfbc930155#file-m1_robsize-c-L390

https://github.com/slothy-optimizer/pqax has all that and is licensed under MIT which means we can take some of that code.

Am I missing something?

At some point it would be nice to have automatic benchmarking on a number of platforms at some point.

comment.body: Completed in #81

issue.title: Add coeff_signed_to_unsigned() functions and its proof
issue.body:
This PR adds _only_ the coeff_signed_to_unsigned() function in poly.c and its proof.

This was previously added in support of the proof of poly_compress(), but that proof is blocked pending CBMC bug fixes.

This PR adds coeff_signed_to_unsigned() in isolation so that proofs of other functions may proceed, such as poly_tobytes()

To run proofs, cd to "cbmc/proofs/coeff_signed_to_unsigned", then either

1. "make" (runs with litani and cbmc-viewer)
or
2. "make -f desktop.mk" (run with command-line CBMC tools only - best for inspecting details results.)

comment.body:
I ran this locally on my x86 machine as well as on a M1 MacMini.
On x86  all tests are passing, on the Mac the `coeff_signed_to_unsigned` fails just like in CI. 
I can't confirm that CI behaves differently than running locally. 

Most obvious thing that is not controlled by nix on Mac is the compiler version, as we are using the native clang on Mac. Could it maybe be related to your issue? I'm more guessing than anything here. 

I have this clang version on the Mac:
```
$ gcc --version
Apple clang version 15.0.0 (clang-1500.3.9.4)
Target: arm64-apple-darwin23.5.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin
```

Can send more outputs if needed.

That's interesteing. I have Apple M1 Pro running macOS 13.6.7 with
```
rodchap@f4d4889dcf6d ~ % gcc --version
Apple clang version 15.0.0 (clang-1500.1.0.2.5)
Target: arm64-apple-darwin22.6.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin
```
and the proof of coeff_signed_to_unsigned() works every time, using both a native shell and running NIX.

I also tried again using a native build of gcc 13.1.0 on PATH before /usr/bin and that also works both with and without NIX.

Using Apple's clang 15 on PATH in /usr/bin/gcc, I just ran
```
goto-cc -E -DCBMC -I../../../fips202 -I../../../mlkem ../../../mlkem/poly.c
```
(using CBMC 6.0.0) and I got the attached file.
[
[poly_clang_expanded.i.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16027984/poly_clang_expanded.i.gz)
](url)
What do you get on the Mac where the proof fails?

```
cbmc --verbosity 6 --object-bits 8 --bounds-check --pointer-check --memory-cleanup-check --div-by-zero-check --signed-overflow-check --unsigned-overflow-check --pointer-overflow-check --conversion-check --undefined-shift-check --enum-range-check --pointer-primitive-check --smt2 ../../../mlkem/poly_contracts.goto
```

issue.title: Add coeff_signed_to_unsigned() functions and its proof
issue.body:
This PR adds _only_ the coeff_signed_to_unsigned() function in poly.c and its proof.

This was previously added in support of the proof of poly_compress(), but that proof is blocked pending CBMC bug fixes.

This PR adds coeff_signed_to_unsigned() in isolation so that proofs of other functions may proceed, such as poly_tobytes()

To run proofs, cd to "cbmc/proofs/coeff_signed_to_unsigned", then either

1. "make" (runs with litani and cbmc-viewer)
or
2. "make -f desktop.mk" (run with command-line CBMC tools only - best for inspecting details results.)

comment.body:
I feel very stupid.

For the "--smt2" option to work, you need "z3" on PATH, or it just silently says "ERROR". Can we add z3 to the NIX config?

comment.body:
I can't push to this branch, but if you apply the following patch, it should install 4.8.17
```
diff --git a/flake.nix b/flake.nix
index d0efeaa..bcce88a 100644
--- a/flake.nix
+++ b/flake.nix
@@ -61,6 +61,7 @@
                 yq
                 ninja# 1.11.1
                 qemu# 8.2.4
+                z3# 4.8.17
                 cadical;
 ```
 
 Can we try that first or do we need a specific version? 
 There is also `z3_4_12` (4.12.5) that's prepackaged in the nix repo. 
 If you need anything newer, we have to compile from source.

issue.title: Benchmarking on A55

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Mainly added a flag `-w`/`--exec-wrapper` for `bench` command allowing user to pass in there custom wrapper for running the benchmark binary.
```
Usage: tests bench [OPTIONS]

Options:
...
  -w, --exec-wrapper TEXT         Run the benchmark binary with the user-
                                  customized wrapper.
```

This is due to for some target machines, we might not be able to compile direcly on the machine, so we would need to cross compile, and then run the binary remotely. See https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/pull/82#issuecomment-2196212811

The current github bench ci looks ugly, will fix it after getting everything working.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body: This is now functional as far as I can tell. The CI yml needs some clean up, but I'm afraid that has to wait until next week.

issue.title: Add NEON assembly for rejection sampling

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Improve the performance of Rejection Sampling. 

I should re-arrange the instructions, but I think when we have SLOTHY figures our the best instruction sequences, so I left it as future work. 

Performance improvement: average 8%. 

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

issue.title: Add NEON assembly for rejection sampling

labels.name: benchmark
labels.description: this PR should be benchmarked in CI

issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Improve the performance of Rejection Sampling. 

I should re-arrange the instructions, but I think when we have SLOTHY figures our the best instruction sequences, so I left it as future work. 

Performance improvement: average 8%. 

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->
